name: Layered Architecture
desc: Organizes the system into horizontal groups (e.g., UI, Business, Data).
cons: Can add latency if there are too many layers.

name: Model-View-Controller
desc: Separates the application into Data (Model), Interface (View), and Control (Controller).
cons: Controller can become bloated ('Massive View Controller').

name: Client-Server
desc: Separates who consumes (Client) from who provides (Server) resources.
cons: Server is a single point of failure and bottleneck.

name: Pipe and Filter
desc: Processing in sequential steps where the output of one is the input of the next.
cons: Difficult to manage global state or errors mid-flow.

name: Service-Oriented Arch
desc: Complete systems expose reusable services via standardized contract.

name: Microservices
desc: Small autonomous services that do one thing well.

name: Event-Driven Arch
desc: Components react to events (facts that occurred) asynchronously.
cons: Difficult to trace flow (debug) and eventual consistency.

name: Hexagonal Architecture
desc: Isolates the application core (domain) from external technologies via Ports and Adapters.
pros: Total testability of the core without database/UI.

name: Peer-to-Peer (P2P)
desc: Decentralized network where each node is client and server.

name: Saga Pattern
desc: Manages long transactions in distributed services via compensation.
pros: Maintains consistency without locking the database.

name: Facade
desc: Provides a simplified interface to a complex subsystem.

name: Adapter
desc: Allows classes with incompatible interfaces to work together.

name: Microkernel (Plugin)
desc: Minimal core with extended functionality via plugins.

name: Broker
cons: Single point of failure if not clustered.

name: Publish-Subscribe
desc: Publishers send messages to topics without knowing who the subscribers are.

name: Blackboard
desc: Independent specialists collaborate by writing to a shared space.
